title: Anne of the Black Hair
subtitle: Mobile Running Game
summary: Did you know that Anne was actually black haired? Maybe you did, but no one in the village should.

content.value: /img/projects/AnneoftheBlackHair2.png

In this running game, no one in the village should know that she is black haired. Change your route to avoid the villagers' eyes and safely deliver the fruit as Marilla asked. Be especially careful not to be seen by children — they spread rumors the fastest! If you lose all the fruit or the news of Anne’s black hair spreads throughout the village, the game is over.

title: reICEcle
subtitle: Point-Based Ice Pack Recycling Application
where: 2021 Software Engineering and Creative Design Project
summary:
Prototype of a Mobile Application  
 that aims to **collect ice packs from households**  
 and **rewards users with points**.  
 These points can be used at local businesses,  
 helping to **boost sales that have declined   
 due to COVID-19**.

content.value: Development of 'reICEcle' began by brainstorming recent problems and narrowing them down to four key issues. After defining solutions for each, we analyzed their feasibility, demand, and relevance, selecting the final topic. We then conducted a thorough investigation using the '5 Whys method' to define the true problem, followed by in-depth research into the severity of the issue, current solutions, and similar case studies. After collecting data, we grouped similar ideas and clearly defined the core features of the 'Point-based Ice Pack Recycling Service System.'
/img/projects/reICEcle1.png

In the detailed design phase of the project, we specifically defined the user environment and development environment, created service usage scenarios, and developed use case diagrams and use case lists to form an overview of the system. Based on this, we then created detailed scenarios for each use case and drew sequence diagrams.
/img/projects/reICEcle2.png
Next, we refined the detailed features by creating functional structure diagram, feature list, and mapping the functions to the screens.
/img/projects/reICEcle3.png
We then designed the screen layouts and transition flow diagrams, followed by protocol design, and ultimately developed the final prototype.

title: Sun the Light
subtitle: Classic PC Shooting Game
summary: Helios, the God of the Sun has lost his Sun one day. Let’s go find out what happened to his Sun, with the Golden Chariot.

content.value: /img/projects/SunTheLight.jpg

This classic PC shooting game captures the mythological journey of Helios and the tension surrounding his struggle to maintain control over the Sun, blending ancient myth with an action-packed adventure.
/img/projects/SunTheLight1.gif

Helios, the First God of the Sun, rises from the eastern palace and sinks into the land of the Hesperides in the west each day. However, the Sun mysteriously vanishes one day, while he was dozing off for a while. So, unfortunately, Helios must embark on a quest to recover it, risking his fame and his fragile position in Olympus. This scenario is given through the animation at the beginning of the game.
/img/projects/SunTheLight2.gif

The player controls the golden chariot, avoiding or attacking light winds, strong winds, and dark clouds. Bumping onto the winds and clouds causes immediate damage, while successfully attacking them results in points. Additionally, if the chariot is driven too low, villages will burn, and if driven too high, the screams of constellations will be heard. In both cases, the player will take damage. The player can use a skill that shoots fire in all directions at regular intervals.
/img/projects/SunTheLight3.gif
At level 3, Helios gets to meet the Boss mob, Dionysos. Or maybe... another one later on. Guess who's coming next with the thunder light striking out after a danger sign.
/img/projects/SunTheLight4.gif
Player gets to find out what happened to Helios, Dyonisos, and Zeus with Game Over / Clear Animation.

title: HalmaeYakson
subtitle: Household Medicine Delivery Service Application
where: EWHA Abeek Design-Thinking Prototype Development Education Award-winning work
summary: Prototype of s Delivery Service Application for Household Medicines and Other Supplies.

content.value: /img/projects/HalmaeYakson1.png

'HalmaeYakson' is an award-winning application aimed at addressing a critical issue for single-person households. Our design process began by defining our primary user persona, Se-eun Lee, and identifying the challenges she faced. We focused on safely delivering medicines and other medical supplies to individuals living alone, particularly women, who need assistance when they are unwell. To provide a solution, we developed an application named 'HalmaeYakson (Grandma's Healing Hands)', inspired by the traditional Korean children's song, 'Grandma's Hands are Healing Hands.' Following the ideation stage, we proceeded with screen design and prototype development, ultimately presenting our completed concept. Our work was recognized for its innovation and user-centered approach.

title: Eat:WHA
subtitle: Ewha Campus Restaurant Guide Web Application
summary: Eat:WHA, the future we crEATe! – A Web Application for Busy Ewha Students to Find the Best Restaurants around campus.

content.value: /img/projects/EatWHA1.png
Eat:WHA is an intuitive web application that allows users to check a list of restaurants around Ewha Campus based on location, using a cute map feature.

I was responsible for the UI design and backend development of the whole web page, which includes features such as sign-up, login, logout, and account deletion, as well as restaurant search, menu browsing, themed lists, liking functionality, vegan badges, writing and viewing reviews.

title: Jeogiyo
subtitle: VUI Application for Assisting Contactless Ordering Services in Stores
summary: Virtual Assistant Application that helps middle-aged and older adults to easily use contactless ordering services at stores by VUI (Voice User Interface).

content.value: 'Jeogiyo' is a personal virtual assistant application designed to help middle-aged and older adults use contactless services with ease. We made a goal to eliminate barriers in digital interactions by improving accessibility and simplifying complex user interfaces.
/img/projects/Jeogiyo1.png

To validate the need for our service, we conducted a survey, which revealed that individuals over the age of 40 find current contactless systems (e.g. kiosk) difficult to use due to complex operations, poor readability, and insufficient guidance.
/img/projects/Jeogiyo.png

To address these challenges, we developed 'Jeogiyo', a virtual assistant application that enhances the user experience through conversational interactions. 'Jeogiyo' activates through voice commands and provides real-time responses, ensuring seamless transactions with minimal effort. The system supports multiple interface types, including voice interaction and typing, for greater accessibility.
/img/projects/Jeogiyo2.png
Key functional and non-functional requirements were determined to ensure effortless use with minimal device operation.
